element_texts.text: Completed

in pencil in top margin  [June 12 1964]
Friday, morning,
Dear Jack
I just got your letter, forwarded from Cambridge.  I'll arrive on Monday around 5 pm but I must join at once the Conference on Higher Education at the University of Chicago ( [?] Ave.) It lasts until Friday 15 noon.  After that date, I'll be most happy to stay with you for a few days.  But anyway I'll call you and I hope I can see you before that date - though the schedule of the conference they sent me seems made so as to leave us no rest!

  My wife just had a baby.  It is a second boy.

All my best - and thanks again
Michael
Excuse this letter, I'm in a hurry to reach you.
Completed

GREENWICH VILLAGE   A scene of the open-air art exhibition held in the spring and fall.  Artists and craftsmen exhibit their wares on all available open space.
Mr Jack Conroy
7027 South Jeffery Blvd
Chicago  Ill
Dear Jack.
Thank you for your 2 cards.  I'm sailing tomorrow, when you'll fly back!   I hope all your trips were successful and I wish you all the best.  Many thanks for everything.  My address will be 26 des Parc ?  Paris 14.  Let's keep in touch!  Love to Gladys.  All my ?  Rachel
Completed

IMAGE  postcard
painted scene of ships on water, pedestrians behind fence, some looking at boats
Completed

postcard
Dec. 14 1964
Dear Mr Conroy,
It was both an honor and a pleasure to receive your book and I am deeply touched.  I had read it  in the former edition and I agree that D. Aarons introduction puts it in a new perspective.  I see from the reviews that it was very well received again.  May I keep the clippings or do you want me to send them back to you?  What I like especially about The Disinherited, in comparison with many novels of the Depression, is what we French would call its classicism:  the narrative is dense and the apparent matter of factness of the tone makes the restrained emotion the more powerful.
I hope that you are getting well - quickly - and I send you my very best wishes for the New Year
Very thankfully yours
Michel Fabre
PS:  I wrote to Henrietta Weigel who replied that she would see me.  crossed out:  which I shall go to New York shortly after Xmas and hope to see her at that time.

postcard caption:  Musée d'Art Moderne (École Française).
Completed

for our appartment.) [sic]   I have also been lately appointed a kind of adviser on Educational Television:  I know strictly nothing about it, but I am able to understand and translate reports from U.S. educators on expirements [sic] and new techniques.  It is a 200 hours contract for three or six months.  Also I am going to teach summer school in July and August -at a NDEA Language Institute in Toulouse.  I shall have mostly conversation courses with 80 american teachers all together.  I have also written one or two articles on Henry Green, an English novelist, and on American Negro Literature for a couple of papers- but it takes too much time, and I am now trying to concentrate upon my thesis.

   Spring has come to Paris and everything is simply delightful.  People walk leisurely, without their coats, women begin to look feminine again and children are everywhere.  Pierre and Jean-Marc are so happy to be able to go outdoors.  Jean-Marc who was born roughly when I saw you is nine months now and he begins to stand up and will walk soon... By the time you come and see us he will begin to talk.  I do hope you will be able to fly over this summer.   I shall be in Toulouse until August 15, then may go to England (London) for a while and will  spend the rest in the country.  But I'll come to Paris when you are there to welcome you this time.  How is Gladys?  And your family at Midlothian?  I had my students translated from THE DISINHERITED the other day, the piece describing the arrival of "pipe line huskies" in the little town all dozing with the depression.  They appreciated "dulce and decorum est...".  French students are very politically aware, I feel, and have what I would call sound reactions, they do not hesitate to demonstrate -even though there is so much inertia in the De Gaulle regime.  Sunday was election day for city councils.  The UNR (gaullists) had manoeuvered [sic] to oust out the communist councils from the "red suburbs"  -the banlieue Sud where we live- but no change occured, [sic] and the UNR even lost 25% of the polls they had got last time though they kept their seats...
  We shall be going to my parents' in law family-home for Easter -from April 7 to April 22, after that I shall serve as an interpreter to a former superintendent of parks of Cook County, Mr Charles Sauers, who is spending two weeks in Paris on a kind of business trip, visiting forests.  I hope that will be rather restful and a kind of holiday - and I also hope I can WORK (i.e. Write) welle [sic] during the vacation itself.   One has never finished.

in left margin in red ink  If you find time tell me more about you and your present occupations - literary
or ? and about Gladys, give her my best - With all my thanks and good
wishes, I am Michel
P.S.  I have two copies of the C. Miscellany.  Do you page folded over text me to send you back one (in
case you need it for yourself)?
Completed

May 17, 1966,
Dear Jack:

   Thank you for your letter and the check.  You are very helpful and efficient indeed.
   I have just written, upon the advice of a friend, to the Edition Sociales (a leftist publisher in Paris) about a French edition of underlined:  The Disinherited.  I'll keep you posted.
   I received Anyplace but Here a few days ago.  I  have not had time to read it through yet, but I read parts of it.  It is a wonderful book because you manage to give a lot of information, to keep a general line very clear and to make the book easy and lively, at the same time.   It should be a success.  I'll review it for LES LANGUES MODERNES, but it may take some time before being published (next winter or spring).  I'll inquire about a French edition, too.  How are the reviews and sales reports in the U.S?
   Yes, I have heard of B. Traven, but I do not know whether he has been translated.
   I hope you have a pleasant stay in New York.  Maybe you'll see Henrietta.
   Geneviève is quite willing to help with Jay Nash's underlined:  Literary Times but she would need the credentials at precisions about what she is expected to do before we leave Paris for the summer, that is around June 20, if her articles are needed for the Fall issue.
   I am in a rush because I have many things to do before we leave for London, in a week or so.  We hope to stay there about ten days, until June 5.  I'll do some research and visit friends.  We'll take the children with us and it will be a kind of vacation.
   I'll write again soon.  Thanks for sending the stamps back.  All my best to you and Gladys.

Michel
To-day is a nearly general strike.  But I doubt De Gaulle will accept any raise in salaries!
Completed

[[pencilled in top margin:  [1966?]  ]]
postmark:  LONDON, WC  1966

June 2nd
Dear Jack
I got your post card in London.  Am in England for a week with all my family and we enjoy it thoroughly.  I am glad your trip to New York was successful.  It didn't ? (for the novel) with the Edition Sociales but I'll try with another firm whose address they gave me.   Will write soon.  three unclear words to you  best  Michel
Mr Jack Conroy
7027 South Jeffery Blvd
Chicago  60649
USA
Completed

M. Fabre
letterhead  UNIVERSITÉ DE PARIS  FACULTÉ DES LETTRES ET SCIENCES HUMAINES  AVENUE DE LA RÉPUBLIQUE  NANTERRE  (SEINE)  TEL.: 204-34-32

                      NANTERRE, LE             196
                      Référence á rappeler     No..................


Dear Jack,

   Thank you for your proposing to write a review of [[underlined:  Les Noire Américains  it is published by Armand Colin, 103 Boulevard Saint-Michel, Paris 5.

The price is 11 .50 F - (about $2.40)  I  have had good commentaries about it and it may be selling fairly well.   I'll know next year ...

    I know Constance Webb's biography.  It is well documented on the whole but she imagines too much - she is always so to speak within Wright's head.   The other one may be a critical study by Edward Margolies - it is much more earnest.   If it is by someone
Completed

else I'd be much interested to know.  

   All our best wishes to both of you for the New Year

Michel
A good thing they have an exhibition of your books at the University of Missouri.   I've not given  up hope to seeunderlined:  the Disinherited in French....
Completed

IMAGE
Stone tower near water with boat in background and car parked in drive next to tower
Completed

postcard
Mr. Jack Conroy
701 Fisk Ave
Moberly, Mo  65270
USA
Bon souvenir de vacances.  There is not much new except fine weather, scenery and rest.   I am following the events in the US  (Newark) ... My book will be out in August, and I am now working on Wright.  How are you, both of you.   All our best.
Michel
Lostanges 19 Meyssac France
pencil in left margin  [1967?]
Completed

Dear Jack,

 I am writing to Miss Stoddard (and hope to be of help) on University of Paris official paper!
 Thanks for sending the books and material.  They will be of use.  underlined:  Is Paris Burning is to my mind a rather lousy account of the liberation.  I have not seen the picture.  I hope that, thanks to the scholarship, you will come & see me this summer.   I am quite confident that they will let you have it.   underlined:  They should.  Anyway I tried to sound personal, and to create a kind of personal relationship with Miss Stoddard in my letter.   This approach sometimes is better than the purely official one.  Of course I did not have to say more than what I
Completed

thought!

  I'm rather in haste now.  Will write again.

All my best
Michel
You know, you could also prepare an edition of the letters you have from so many writers - It would have a definite documentary interest.  I could help you if you like.
in pencil in bottom margin   [ 1968?]
Completed

I shall probably take agroup [sic] of students around for a nine day trip around that time.  I shall not go to England, for lack of time, but I'll be in Paris from Sept. 20 onwards.  I'll come a fe days in advance if you can come, which I would like very much.   I could probably accomodate you and certainly take you around.  So, please, try and come -with or without Gladys:
  What you tell me about Walter Snow is a revelation to me, because I did not know that he was working for the Communist Party by the time of the underlined; Anvil -PR merger;  his letters to you always gave the impression that Rahv and Philllips were the tools of the party, not him.  I'll be glad to exchange information with Glad Gilbert, though I think, he'll shortly know as much as I do if he concentrates on the Anvil-{R merger.  My main source was, of course, your extensive files and correspondance [sic] - I know Kenneth Kinnamon well.   He is a fine, serious chap, very open minded and more than liberal; a  good scholar, rather erudite.   He is finishing his thesis on Wright, concentrating on the American years.  I gave him a lot of information.
   You give me an idea, with your mentionning [sic] all those books on the thirties.   I think I could do a kind of "chronicle" of them for LES LANGUES MODERNES as I am doing for the next number with Negro literature.  I already have to review the NEW REPUBLIC anthology (the faces of five decades)'  I could add the underlined:  Carleton Miscellanyissue, speak of underlined:  The Disinherited,  (and underlined:  They seek a city, by the way), and include Filler's and Herny [sic] Roth's books.  I could not find underlined:  The Anxious years i Paris, and I would appreciate your bringing it over, with the book on Dreiser if it is not too heavy.  If Roth's books is in papaerback [sic]  I can get it later.
   I would like to ask you something:  I am going to get paid by the NDEA institute I am working for now in such a way that my salary is not reported to the French Tax Offices.  But if I cash the cheques directly here they can be traced back to me if there is any checking.   Would you mind if I sent you my checks, endorsed to your order, you could cash them in your account and either change them into francs crossed out:  or have a cheque in francs made in my name in Chicago which I could cash somewhere in Paris. in Chicago, or in Paris, for me.   I'll get about 1300 $ this summer.  and it's worth saving tax on it.  If you see any inconvenience to that, I can ask another friend.

pencilled in bottom margin  [1960's ?]
handwritten in left margin   I'll try to keep in touch with you this December and write more often.
All my best to you and Gladys.  Michel
Completed

handwritten in top margin    Best to you & Gladys   Michel            April 9, 1972

Dear Jack,

   Here is the money for the things sold to Holtzman.  Remember you were not supposed to have furnished the Traven material if he contacts you.
    I have travelled extensively in the South and the Caribbean since I saw you.  Spent some time with Arna who has not aged a bit, at his place in Nashville.  Spoke at Memphis, Arlington (Texas) and Bishop College in Dallas.  Interviewed people in Martinique and other places.  All very exciting.  I have not forgotten that I'll soon pay you another visit.  This will probably be at the end of the month, if it is OK with you.  I plan to come on Tuesday, work with you at sorting your papers, and leave on Friday to speak for that rather silly ladies' club in Kansas City.  I may bring the children along if Genevieve has to go to Chicago that week.  For the Fall issue of underlined:  New Letters which will be centered on you, I plan to contribute the history of underlined:  Rebel Poets and underlined:  The Anvil I had prepared for my secondary thesis and haven't used yet. handwritten at bottom of card But I'll tell you more soon.  I go to handritten in left margin  Boston - NY on Tuesday → Sat. then to Syracuse & Yale the week after, I think. handwritten in top margin:  Best to you & Gladys  Michel
Completed

Cedar Rapids, 
May 26  12.00
Dear Jack,
I am on my way to Chicago (Blain Writers' conference) where I'll speak on R Wright at 4, then to NY tonight, then to Paris via London on Sunday.  I've mailed you back some of the stuff I borrowed.  I'll send you more soon but I didn't have time to ? it.  Plan to stay 1 month in Paris (℅ Moreau 26 Ave. Coty, Paris 14) and go back to S. Francisco after a few days; stop in Iowa City in very early July for the WEB Dubois Institute.  I'll have a second look at my notes in underlined:  Anvil ? in ? for this underlined:  New Letters article.  Saw Paul Rómaine in Chi. he was charming and sends you his best.  so do Alice Browning, Fern Gayden, and Isa (Rosey Pool's friend) whom I plan to see in London.  My best to you & Gladys - hope you'll both  keep fine & ? your work . . .
Marc will go to Ch. Blocelson, he'll contact us if he wants the galleys    Michel
Completed

Completed

[[pencil in top margin:  Fabre, Michel  [1976]  ]]
Postcard  Thousands of visitors are guest every Summer evening to Chicago's free band concerts.  The beautiful surroundings of Grant Park give an unusual setting to these concerts.
Dear Jack,
May this old-time card bring you our best wishes for 1977.  Especially, that you may be able to go on with the autobiography - The death of "Red" . of whom I was so fond, too, shocked and saddened me - May my friendly & affectionate thoughts bring to you and dear Gladys some warmth and sympathy.  And above all, Jack,  go on with  your biography - you owe it to our era.
?? 2 words ??   Michel
Completed

pencil in top margin  Fabre, Michel   [1979]
Jan 4, '79
Dear Jack,
I haven't moved and am still at Paris III - glad to hear from you after having heard about you from David Ray (Comey Reader) & Doug Wikson.  Recently a colleague who is working for a literary dictionary was asking me about you (life/publications, etc...) and was ? I knew so much about you!  If you & Gladys can find the money for the fare we could arrange to put you up, I suppose, if you came when it is convenient for us.  I plan to go to Louisiana this Spring & work on (black) creoles & cajuns.  Have you any trips?  Read your review of underlined:  Yonnondio in underlined:  NZ - You must have a tremendous list of publications!
Affectionately to you & Gladys   Michel
Michel FABRE
12 square Montsouris
75014 PARIS
Completed

pencil in top margin  Fabre, Michel  [1980]
Dec 26
Dear Jack,

  The publisher for underlined:  Disinherited is bankrupt but, after a court settlement is made, they may be able to go on exploiting its books they had contracted for.  I have also approached another otufit, they are interested.
